If *yi* were in the northeast, why not also call the fifteenth day, when the celestial stems are full, "盛满甲东北"? *Jia* is closer to the northeast yet is not called so—how much less *yi*, which precedes *jia* and leans toward the southeast? Clearly, it is not in the northeast.

"九六亦相当" was explained above under "复卦建始初." "易象索灭藏" refers to the thirtieth night, when the symbols of the sun and moon both sink into the north. One edition mistakenly renders "易象" as "阳."

"象彼仲冬节至以晓后生" was misplaced in the postscript of an old edition. Chen Baoyi moved it before "子当右转," both incorrect. This passage rhymes with two "伤" sounds and, when connected to the earlier "易象索灭藏," also rhymes with two "藏" sounds. Ancient writers often used repeated rhymes, but later readers, not understanding this, recklessly altered the text, disrupting its coherence. Examples include "关睢建始初" with "复卦建始初" and "刚柔相当" with "九六亦相当"—all repeated rhymes. How could such repetitions be hastily dismissed as errors?

"商旅" in one edition reads "贾作商." "浩广" in one version is written as "广作旷."

"眇难睹" in one edition reads "睹作觌." "符征" in one edition reads "征作证." "节令" in one edition reads "节作时." "中稽于人心" in one edition reads "心作情." "依卦变" in one edition reads "循卦节." "循彖辞" in one edition reads "循作因彖作象," which is incorrect.

"乾坤用施行天地然后治" in one edition reads "治作理," while another reads "天下然后治." These two lines appear to quote the *Qian* hexagram’s "Qian yuan yong jiu, tianxia zhi" (When Qian’s primal power is activated through the Nine, all under heaven is well-ordered). However, considering the preceding "Kan and Li are the two functions of Qian and Kun," this suggests Kan and Li serve as the functions of Qian and Kun—not the "yong jiu" (Nine) or "yong liu" (Six). As in the earlier passage "In the east, its brightness is lost," this does not refer to the Kun hexagram’s "In the northeast, one loses one’s companions." Master Wei’s composition of this work largely employs figurative language, and one need not cling rigidly to literal interpretations. "可不慎乎" in one edition reads "可得不慎乎," which is incorrect.

"魁杓" in one edition reads "杓作柄." "誃离即别离也" in one edition reads "移离," while another reads "坎离." "仰俯" in other editions reads "俯仰"; Zhu Xi noted that "仰俯" is the correct reading to preserve the rhyme, and this version follows his emendation. "统录" in one edition reads "统作总." "日含五行精" in one edition reads "含作合," which is incorrect. "诘过贻主" in one edition reads "结过移主." "辰极处正" in one edition reads "处作受," while another reads "正作政." "布政" in one edition reads "政德," which is incorrect. "终修" in one edition reads "修作循," while another reads "中美." "以掩蔽" in one edition reads "以作已."

The presence and absence likewise depend on each other, referring to the mutual reliance of the water and fire *qi* to complete the workings of creation. In some editions, "有无" appears as "金炁" or "吟," both of which are incorrect. "进退分布" in one edition reads "进退作退而," which is incorrect. "采之白" in one edition reads "采作望," while another reads "揺." "白里" in one edition reads "包裹." "相扶" in one edition reads "扶作拘." "相连" in one edition reads "连作通."

"This is not the method of visualizing the Five Viscera" means that this Dao is not the practice of meditating upon and storing thoughts within the five viscera. If one takes the two characters "是非" to mean "right and wrong," one has misunderstood. "次日辰" in one edition reads "次作以," which is incorrect. "累土" in one edition reads "周." "而意悦" in one edition reads "意悦喜."

"To tread through fire without scorching, to enter water without getting wet" describes the state after the Dao is accomplished and the Dharma-body is realized. If one were to cast the flesh-and-blood body into water or fire, how could it merely be a matter of scorching or wetting? "移居" in one edition reads "居作名," which is incorrect. "功满" in one edition reads "满作成," which is incorrect.

"偃月" — given that the following text reads "汞日则偃," it is likely that "铅" was mistakenly transmitted as "鼎." "作鼎炉" in older editions reads "作法," which is incorrect. "亘亦八" in one edition reads "亦如之." "亏明" in one edition reads "明作伤." "金本从日生" — at the new moon, the moon receives the light of the sun, for the moon’s radiance is born from the sun. At the beginning of each month, at dawn, the moon conjoins with the sun. Here, "金火" refers to the sun and moon. In older editions, "日" appears as "月," which is incorrect. If one were to say that "金本从月生," it would be as if saying "月本从月生," which makes no sense.

"数称五" in one edition reads "数作号." "含育" in one edition reads "贪欲." "伫息" refers to the unification of concentrated stillness and the breath, merging the two into one, like the union of husband and wife. In one edition, "息" appears as "思," while in another, it appears as "恩," both of which are incorrect. "执平" in one edition reads "执作气."

"Soil travels through the four seasons, guarding its boundaries and adhering to its rules" — in all editions except Zheng Xu’s, this line appears after "寿命得长久," but in Zheng Xu’s edition, it is placed after "本性共宗祖." "Gold takes cinnabar as its master, harmonizing with mercury" is a direct allusion to the transformation of ordinary cinnabar and mercury, serving as a metaphor for the alchemical process. It does not rely on external objects for comparison or juxtapose internal elements with one another.

"以黍" in one edition reads "黍作粟," which is incorrect. "其卵" in one edition reads "卵作子," which is incorrect. "泥汞" in one edition reads "汞作澒." "炼飞" in one edition reads "飞作治," while another reads "持." "鼓铸" in one edition reads "铸作下," which is incorrect. "杂性不同" in one edition reads "作种."

"Fortunate chance ultimately fails to meet the sage who alone knows it" — the Zhu Xi edition lacks these ten characters. "Engendering doubt" in one edition reads "sitting in doubt." "First sketched the Eight Trigrams, emulating Heaven and Earth" — one edition reads "first sketched the Eight Trigrams, imaging and emulating Heaven and Earth," while another reads "sketched the Eight Trigrams to emulate Heaven’s diagram"; both are incorrect. "Following this" in one edition reads "structuring the body." "All sages" refers to sages without rank; Confucius is one such. One edition reads "sages and" instead, which is incorrect. "Three lords" in one edition reads "three sages." "Making it a model" in one edition reads "making it sincere." "Establishing this book for the world" — this refers to the *Cantong Qi*, as the great Dao of the Golden Elixir is formless and traceless, leaving nothing for later generations to emulate. Thus, this book was established for the world, just as the middle chapter’s "establishing this record" shares the same meaning. Older editions read "establishing the *Book of Poetry* for the world," which is incorrect. "Privately considering" in one edition reads "awaiting." "Presumptuously pondering" in one edition reads "composing this foolishness," which is incorrect.

Gold accounts for fifteen, and the water number is likewise — this refers to the earlier chapter’s "upper *kan* trigram’s *dui* number is eight, and the lower *kan* trigram’s *gen* is also eight." For the upper *kan* is half a *jin* of metal, and the lower *kan* is half a *jin* of water; when the two *kan* are observed together, they form the number of thirty days in a month, though this differs from the meaning of "metal within water." One edition reads "gold accounts for fifteen" as "the gold number is fifteen." Its earth does not enter the two but unites with them; the three substances mutually contain and receive one another, transforming as if by spirit. These three substances are the three elements: metal, water, and earth. Metal and water unite with earth to become one, hence "three substances mutually containing and receiving." If fire were added, it would become five substances. Some interpret the three substances as metal, fire, and wood, and the two as water and fire — such redundancy is far from the ultimate discourse. One edition reads "its earth" as "its three," "the two" as "fire two," and "again as water two," all of which are incorrect. "Pounding and refining" in one edition reads "casting and smelting." "Achieving perfection and hardness" in one edition reads "arriving at" instead of "achieving."

Beneath, the blazing fire spreads forth, while the roars of dragon and tiger grow ever more urgent—this mirrors the later passage’s "ascending and roasting in the steamer-mountain, where the blazing fire is set below." The White Tiger leads the way, and the Azure Dragon follows in harmony, both conveying the same meaning. Older editions render "dragon and tiger" as "day and night," which is incorrect.

At the outset, the text must be cultivable—one edition reads "at the very beginning, the text must be cultivable." "Personally witness" is rendered in one edition as "mutually intimate," and in another as "must be intimate." "To ingest it" appears in one edition as "to grind and lift," in another as "to grind and knead," and in yet another as "to lift and grind"—all incorrect. "One pellet" is written in one edition as "one origin," and in another as "one grain"—both incorrect. The *daogui* refers merely to the tip of a knife’s corner, signifying its small quantity. If one interprets the knife as metal and the *gui* as the two earths, the craft may be clever, yet it strays from Master Wei’s original intent.

"Comparatively concise" appears in one edition as "simplified." "Radiant" is rendered in one edition as "flourishing"—incorrect. "Gradual erosion" is written in one edition as "violent erosion." "Manifesting dragon and tiger" appears in one edition as "inscribing dragon and tiger." "Auspicious Yellow Sprout" is written in one edition as "added Yellow Sprout."

**Middle Section**
In concert with the workings of creation—one edition reads "must" instead of "in concert," and another reads "at the beginning." "Primal foundation" appears in one edition as "mysterious foundation," and in another as "primal mold." The sixty hexagrams are employed, spreading forth as a chariot—one edition reads "encircling" instead of "employed," which is incorrect. "Without deviation" appears in one edition as "without embankment." "Toppling the precarious state" is written in one edition as "toppling the state’s precariousness." "Hexagram days" appears in one edition as "hexagram months." "Each of the sixty hexagrams has its own days" is written in one edition as "the remaining sixty hexagrams"—incorrect in meaning. "Establishing punishments" is written in an older edition as "standing punishments." "Celestial stems and earthly branches" appears in one edition as "celestial stems and nights." "With focused intent" is written in one edition as "treacherous rebels," and in another as "scattering in all directions." "One’s own mouth" appears in one edition as "the cauldron." "Its arrival" is written in one edition as "the center." "Hard and soft are decisively severed, never intermingling"—the earlier section speaks of the insubstantial controlling the substantial, which has already been explained below.

Between the dark of the moon and the new moon, the tally aligns and moves through the center to begin in the northeast, the region of *Ji* and *Dou*. For the dark of the moon and the new moon occur between *hai* and *zi*, when the sun and moon conceal themselves; the region of *Ji* and *Dou* lies between *gen* and *yin*, where the sun and moon begin their revolution. This is used to illustrate the subtlety of the elixir method, which follows the same path as heaven and earth, sun and moon. Some, however, directly take the period between *gen* and *yin* as the time between the dark and new moon, when the first yang arises and the medicine is gathered—yet this is far from the mark.

Turning to the right and revolving, the wheel of fire vomits forth its sprouts: when the yang fire revolves from the waist through *Dou* and *Ji* upward to the *Xuan* Pass, its radiance shines beyond the curtains. One edition reads "turning to the left" instead of "turning to the right." Above *Mao* and *Bi*, *Zhen* emerges as the omen—this refers to the moon’s first appearance in the west, its form like *Zhen*, used to illustrate the fire phases within the body. If one were to discuss the moon’s rising position according to the directions of the *Xiantian* Eight Trigrams, then *Zhen* of the *Xiantian* is not in the west, nor is the fire-phase *Zhen* in the west. Failing to recognize its true locus, one merely sees the contradictions in the explanations.

"Harmonious peace" appears in one edition as "initial peace." "Its unity" appears in one edition as "yin unity."

Six Five of *Kun* denotes the thirty-day period—this is not referring to the sixth line of the *Kun* hexagram. When the yang numbers have reached their term, they then recommence. Following the emotions to align with nature, they turn and unite. All editions place this under "the compass and square of the Dao," except for Master Zhu’s edition, which places it under "the mother of the world"—this is incorrect.

"Circulating through the six lines"—one edition reads *liu* as *zhang*—incorrect.
"Difficult to"—one edition reads *yi* as *ke*.
"Flourishing"—one edition reads *zhang* as *heng*.
"Generating radiance"—one edition reads *sheng* as *zheng*—incorrect.
"Gradually advancing"—one edition reads *jian* as *jin*.
"Completing *Tai*"—one edition reads *cheng* as *cheng* (to bear).
"Moving"—one edition reads *er* as *yi*.
"Elm pods"—one edition reads *jia* as *ye*—incorrect.
"Vibrating and seeking"—one edition reads *suo* as *jing*.

Yang ends in the center of *Si*, interacting—this refers to the fourth month, which belongs to *Ji*, corresponding to the *zhonglü* pitch. Master Xiashan, Zhan Gu, in his annotated edition, writes *zhong* as *zhonglü*—one edition writes *zhong* as *wu*—incorrect. *Wu* serves as the guest; one edition reads it as the host.

"Withdrawing from the world and relinquishing position"—one edition reads *qu wei* as *qu shi wei*—incorrect.
"Its essence"—one edition reads *qi* as *zhen*.
Yin expands while yang contracts, damaging name and reputation—this refers to the seventh month, which belongs to *Shen*, corresponding to the *yize* pitch. *Shen* is expansion, *yi* is injury. An old edition writes "damaging" as "submerging yang"; one edition writes "submerging" as "extolling"—both incorrect.
"Dissipating and vanishing"—one edition reads *mie* as *xi*—incorrect.
"Utmost spirit"—one edition reads *zhi* as *qi*; one edition reads *shen* as *kun*.

"Decline and flourishing"—one edition reads *shuai* as *geng*—incorrect.
"Serving and attending"—one edition reads *cheng* as *yong*.
"For a thousand autumns"—one edition reads *qiu* as *zai*.
"Utterly none"—one edition reads *wu* as *yuan*—incorrect.
"Flowing and spreading"—one edition reads *liu* as *yun*.
"Like a chicken’s egg, to the flesh smooth as maltose"—an old edition misplaces this phrase, likely having mistakenly transposed it for the sake of rhyme; it has now been corrected. "Like"—one edition reads *xiang* as *zhuang*. "Supporting"—one edition reads *fu* as *fu* (talisman). "Complete"—one edition reads *ju* as *ju* (both). "As maltose"—an old edition reads *yi* as *qian*; Master Zhu’s edition corrects it to *yi*.
*Jin* and *e* were explained in the preceding section.
"Constantly"—one edition reads as *zhu gu*; one edition reads as *zhu wan*; one edition reads as *zhu yuan*.
"At this time, emotions harmonize with Heaven and Earth"—one edition reads *yuan chu zhi shi you hu qian kun*.
"Constrained, then water settles"—one edition reads *ze shui ding huo wu xing zhi chu*. "The Dao has no form or image"—an old edition reads *wu* as *zhi*, for in antiquity the character *wu* (無) was written similarly to *zhi* (之), and in cursive script they resemble each other, leading to the error. One edition reads *xiang* as *zhuang*.
"The True One is difficult to depict"—one edition reads *yi* as *qi*.
"Utmost suspension"—one edition reads as *xuan qie*—incorrect.

The ear, eye, and mouth are the Three Treasures—one edition reads "the treasures of the ear, eye, and self," which is incorrect. "Exalting"—one edition reads *tong* for *yang*. "Seeing and observing"—one edition reads *ting* for *lan*. "Accord with the primordial chaos"—one edition reads "accord *with* the primordial." "Thought after thought"—an old edition reads "no thought." "Verification shifts of itself"—an old edition reads "verification is difficult to shift," which is incorrect. "*Jin* with"—one edition reads "with *jin*." "Penetrating the boundless"—one edition reads *run* for *dong*, which is incorrect. "Within the valley"—one edition reads "Central Palace"; one edition reads "within the vessel," both of which are incorrect. "Relying on the staff"—one edition reads "leaning on the staff." "Submerged in water"—one edition reads *tou* for *mo*. "Obtaining millet"—one edition reads the second *huo* for the first. "No merit seen"—one edition reads "not" as "none." "Utmost simplicity"—one edition reads *shi* for *zhi*, which is incorrect, for in cursive script *zhi* (至) and *shi* (事) resemble each other.

"Then they interlock, swallow, chew, and devour one another"—the old edition, Peng Zhenyi’s annotation, and the Southern Song Liu Yongnian edition all place these lines under "the loving mother nurtures, the filial son repays kindness." Master Zhu states: "Now, upon examination, these two lines naturally belong to the following passage, 'all mutually covet and merge,' where the four lines form a continuous sequence of meaning and should not be here." This humble commentator observes: this chapter uses the affection between mother and child as a metaphor, for the phrase "then they interlock and swallow" signifies the young crow repaying its mother, and thus it properly belongs here. Now, following the old edition, it is moved to its correct position.

"Three and five become one"—this refers to the preceding section’s *zi-wu* numbers combining: three *wu* and five *ji* numbers. It differs from the *Three-Five Unity* in the *Wuzhen Pian*. One edition reads *yu* for *wei*, which is incorrect.

"The child should turn right"—this means the tiger is born within water. "Noon revolves eastward"—this means the dragon emerges from within fire. *Zi* and *wu* are water and fire. "The child should turn right" refers to the conjunction of metal and water, turning right to reach *zi*. "Noon revolves eastward" refers to wood and fire as companions, revolving eastward to reach *wu*. The Dao of returning cinnabar follows the same pattern as the celestial Dao of left-revolving and right-turning. If one says *zi* turns right to reach *you* and *wu* revolves eastward to reach *mao*, this would be right-revolving and left-turning, opposing the celestial Dao. "Eastward revolving"—one edition reads *zuo* for *dong*. "Host and guest"—one edition reads *ding* for *ke*. "Coveting and merging"—one edition reads *bian* for *bing*; one edition reads *rong*, both of which are incorrect.

Each attains its nature—one edition reads *you* for *de* and *gong* for *xing*. "Ascertaining"—one edition reads *you* for *shen*. "Attains the correct Dao"—one edition reads *wei* for *cheng*. "The father bestows and grants"—one edition reads *sheng* for *zhu*, which is incorrect. "The hen"—one edition reads *fei* for *pin*. "The Dao of transformation"—one edition reads *gong* for *dao*, and another reads *jing*, both of which are incorrect. "At the inception of receiving qi"—one edition reads *yuan* for *zhi*. "Daily transformation, monthly change"—this borrows from Zhuangzi’s phrasing; one edition reads *ri shou yue hua*, which is incorrect. Another suspects *ri shou yue hua* contradicts principle and thus alters it to *yue shou ri hua*, which is also incorrect. "The nature of water is all-encompassing"—one edition reads *he rong* for *zhou zhang*. "Wood and fire as companions"—this means the dragon emerges from within fire, with three in the east and two in the south together forming five. "The conjunction of metal and water"—this means the tiger is born toward water, with one in the north and four in the west completing it. Zhang Ziyang’s statement that the four images do not depart from the two bodies precisely refers to this. Some later interpretations, placing *li* of the Earlier Heaven sequence after *zhen* and *dui* of the Later Heaven to elucidate this, not only miss Master Wei’s original intent but also contradict the great process of inner transformation. One edition reads *jin mu* for *jin shui* and *shui huo* for *mu huo*, which is gravely mistaken. "Arranged"—one edition reads *he* for *lie*, and another reads *yin*. "The heart is red, thus female"—one edition omits these four characters.

"At *zi*, the Five Phases begin"—one edition omits these four characters; another reads *ju* for *zi*. "Establishing the weft"—one edition reads *wei* as *position*. "*Xu* and *Wei*"—one edition reads *embracing the true*. "Grasping fire"—one edition reads *descending to sit*. "Harmonizing"—one edition reads *grasping fire*. "Indulging vain hopes"—one edition reads *hoping for expectations*.

**Lower Section**
Only the sages and worthies of old embraced the mysterious and held fast to the true, deeply pitying later generations who loved the Dao. Following the currents of influence, they inscribed ancient texts and composed diagrams and scriptures to enlighten posterity, revealing branches while concealing roots. This means that the sages of antiquity, having attained the Dao and embraced the mysterious while holding fast to the true, pitied those of later generations who loved the Dao yet could not grasp its teachings. Thus, they followed the currents of influence, citing antiquity to validate the present, composing diagrams and scriptures to instruct them. Yet they dared not expound it too directly, so they employed the designations of the Five Metals and Eight Stones to elucidate it. The so-called composition of diagrams and scriptures under the guise of various stones refers to the sages of old acting thus—not to those of later generations who loved the Dao. In this chapter, Peng Zhen and Chen Baoyi both misunderstood this; only Master Zhu’s commentary correctly grasped its meaning.

"Three Origins"—one edition reads *light* for *origin*, which is incorrect. "Essence overflows"—one edition reads *fluids*, which is incorrect.

"Transforming form"—one edition reads *transform* as *change*, which is incorrect. "Overturning and distorting numerous texts" means to repeatedly confuse and disorder their words rather than daring to leak them directly. One edition reads *distort* as *conceal*, which is incorrect. "Transmitted through the ages"—one edition reads *transmit* as *raise*. "Not serving"—one edition reads *serving* as *thus*. "Thus producing disordered words"—one edition reads *producing* as *not*, which is incorrect. "Mysterious channel"—one edition reads *channel* as *distant*. "Retreating from behind"—an old edition reads *behind* as *reform*, which is incorrect.

"Bolts and bars rise and fall"—*the heavens in their circuit* then rush forth. In old editions, both characters for *the heavens in their circuit* were written as *zhou-hai*; Master Zhu suspected *zhou-hai* lacked coherent meaning and thus emended it to *harm qi*, which is also incorrect. The character *harm* resembles *zhou*, while *hai* is quite close to *heaven*.

"The Yangtze and Yellow Rivers never run dry"—*water flows into the sea*. An old edition reads *not* for *into*, which is incorrect. The error of *not* for *into* was explained in detail under "the Dao has no form" in the middle section. One edition reads *Yellow River* as *Huai River*. "Ending and returning to the beginning"—one edition reads *returning to the beginning and ending*; another reads *returning to renew the beginning*. "Spread forth"—one edition reads *forth* as *establish*. "White Tiger"—one edition reads *Tiger* as *alum*, which is incorrect. "Azure Dragon"—one edition reads *Dragon* as *fluid*, which is incorrect. "Pressing and halting"—one edition reads *halting* as *into*. "Dragon’s scales, armor, and mane"—one edition reads *Dragon* as *fish* and *armor* as *frivolous*, which is incorrect. "Joining and linking"—one edition reads *linking* as *jumbled*. "Guarding one another"—one edition reads *one another* as *and thus."

The Chamber-Six—one edition reads *Six* as *Seven*, which is incorrect. *Upright Yang*—one edition reads *Yang* as *Yin*, which is incorrect. "The Three and Five converge with Danger as one, all gathering in one place"—this refers to the qi of Chamber-Six, Strung-Seven, Extended-Two, and Three Directions merging with the North’s Danger-One, all assembling and returning to a single locus. At its core lies the workings of creation: the Southern Extended and Northern Danger correspond to the moon, while the Eastern Chamber and Western Pleiades correspond to the sun. Danger-One combined with Chamber-Six forms the generative and completive numbers of Water; Extended-Two combined with Strung-Seven forms the generative and completive numbers of Fire. Chamber-Six in the East and Extended-Two in the South—Wood and Fire as companions—combine Six and Two to make Eight. Pleiades-Seven in the West and Danger-One in the North—Metal and Water in union—combine Seven and One to make Eight, corresponding to the weight of two eights as one jin. This is what is meant by "rooted in but two things." One edition reads *converge with Danger as one* as *converge to become one*; another reads *as one* as *with one*—both are incorrect. Another edition reads *one place* as *two places*, which is also incorrect. One must recognize that in Master Wei’s composition of this work, not a single phrase fails to accord with the workings of creation. If one were to suppose that "the Three and Five with the One all gather in two places," where then would the workings of creation reside? Moreover, the notion of "two places" is especially egregious. Even if one were to insist on calling it "two places," one should speak of *division* rather than *gathering*; if speaking of *gathering*, one should speak of *one place* rather than *two places*.

*Qu-fu*—Jiaxia Mountain’s commentary reads *Fu-qu*. "Crimson hue penetrating inner and outer"—one edition reads *crimson-black penetrating inner and outer*. *Millet grain*—one edition reads *millet* as *rice*, which is incorrect. "If the qi of mountains and marshes steams forth"—one edition reads *the qi of mountains and marshes mutually steams forth*, which is incorrect. *For a hundred million generations*—one edition reads *generations* as *eras*. *And may be examined*—one edition reads *and* as *of itself*. *Heart-spirit*—one edition reads *heart* as *defense*. *Suddenly self-awakens*—one edition reads *suddenly* as *abruptly*. *Receiving the celestial charts*—one edition reads *charts* as *records of celestial charts*, which is incorrect.

*Tripod Vessel Song*: "Diameter of one fen"—an old edition reads *diameter* as *ten*. "Length of one chi two"—one edition reads *one chi two* as *two chi*, which is incorrect.

The abdomen’s *qi*-alignment—Zhu Xi notes that *qi* (齐) is the ancient form of *navel* (脐); one edition reads *five qi-alignments* (五齐), which is incorrect. "Head and tail are *wu*, the center is *wen*"—this refers to the new and full moons as head and tail, and the full moon as the center. Head and tail are thus one realm, and the center is likewise one realm. If one claims that *si* (巳) is yang and *zi* (子) is the tail, *wu* (午) is yin and *hai* (亥) is the head, with *si* and *wu* facing each other as the center, then there would be two heads and tails and two centers. Another interpretation holds that when advancing yang fire, *zi* (子), *chou* (丑), and *yin* (寅) form the head, while *chen* (辰) and *si* (巳) form the tail; when retreating yin符, *wu* (午), *wei* (未), and *shen* (申) form the head, while *xu* (戌) and *hai* (亥) form the tail, with the central palace as the center—thus two heads, two tails, and one center. Neither interpretation is sound.

*Two sevens gather*—one edition reads *gather* as *orifice* (窍), which is incorrect.
*Examining the brain’s principles*—one edition reads *examining* (赡) as *gazing* (瞻), another as *gallbladder* (胆), both incorrect.

**Preface**
The *Three Correlations* (三相䚸) refer to the mutual resemblance in yin-yang transformation among the *Great Change* (易), the *Yellow and Lao* (黄老), and furnace fire. Since Peng Zhenyi depicted the five phases with wood as three, fire as two, earth as five, metal as four, and water as one—forming a diagram of *five positions mutually attuned, each with its harmony*—later generations all followed Peng’s interpretation, mistakenly attributing it to Wei Boyang’s original text and conflating it with the *correlation of the five phases* (五行之相䚸). This error has persisted to this day without correction. Yet none have considered what Wei Boyang truly meant by *correlation*. Moreover, the *Change*’s *five positions mutually attuned, each with its harmony* refers to the harmonization of the five phases’ generating and completing numbers. Peng’s system uses only the generating numbers—how can this be called *five positions mutually attuned, each with its harmony*? Some argue that wood as three and fire as two form one five, metal as four and water as one form another five, with central earth as five completing three fives—this might still be called *three fives correlated* (三五相䚸). But to speak of the *correlation of the five phases* (五行之相䚸) is untenable, for water is one, fire is two, and the numbers of metal, wood, and earth each differ—how can they be correlated? One edition reads *mutually correlated* (互相䚸), which is somewhat plausible, though far less clear than the *Three Correlations*.

Examining the subsequent text, it states: *"The Three Ways emerge from the One, sharing the same path"* and *"Arrayed as three branches, stems interconnected, differing in name yet issuing from one gate"*—the meaning of *Three Correlations* is thus unmistakably evident.

*Guo of Kuai*—Wei Boyang’s self-reference. Wei was from Shangyu in Guiji; by calling it *Guo of Kuai* instead of Guiji, he avoided revealing his native place. To read it directly as Guiji would be a later emendation, not Wei’s original wording.

*Embracing simplicity*—one edition reads *embracing simplicity and holding purity* (怀朴抱素).
*Unfond of power and glory*—meaning he refused to delight in power and glory. *Delight* (乐) should be read in the departing tone; one edition reads *power* (权) as *joy* (欢), which is incorrect.
*Profit and fame*—one edition reads *profit* (利) as *command* (令).
*Leisurely dwelling in seclusion*—one edition reads *distant traveler in leisure* (远客燕闲).
*Observing his inclinations*—one edition reads *inclinations* (所) as *purport* (旨).
*Shared principles*—one edition reads *principles* (伦) as *discourse* (论).
*Disseminating transformation*—one edition reads *disseminating* (施) as *spiritual* (神).
*Returning to the root*—one edition reads *root* (根) as *foolish* (愚), which is incorrect.
*My heart*—one edition reads *heart* (心) as *form* (形).
*Eight minerals*—one edition reads *eight* (八) as *five* (五).
*Perfecting things*—one edition reads *things* (物) as *achievement* (功).

The text "Committing to the times, departing from harm, relying on hills and mountains, roaming the vast expanse, neighboring with spirits" through "securely attaining long life"—these sixteen phrases encapsulate the three characters of Wei Boyang. "Each mutually bearing" refers to: *committing to spirits* mutually bearing forms *Wei*; *people* and *white* mutually bearing forms *Bo*; *阝* and *sun* mutually bearing forms *Yang*. One edition reads *spirits* (鬼) as *immortals* (仙), *narrow pass* (阨) as *calamity* (厄). "Each mutually bearing, securely attaining long life" is rendered as "Auspicious people mutually bearing, peacefully attaining long life." Another edition reads: "Auspicious people mutually bearing, securely attaining long life." Both are incorrect. Yet another edition reads *east, west, south, and slanting* (东西南倾) as *east, west, south, and north* (东西南北), and *drought and flood* (水旱) as *drought, flood, and warfare* (水旱兵革).

**Eulogy and Preface**
*Establishing governance*—one edition reads *governing the realm* (御极).
*Rice and salt*—this adopts the language of the *Tianguan Shu* in the *Records of the Grand Historian*. "Rice and salt" signifies clear division, like black and white. One edition reads *rice and salt* (米盐) as *Kan and Li* (坎离), which is incorrect.
*With the Yi*—one edition reads *Yi* (易) as *classic* (经).
*Establishing commentary*—one edition reads *commentary* (注) as *method* (法), which is incorrect.
*For this*—one edition reads *this* (此) as *I* (吾).

After the three chapters of the *Zhouyi Cantong Qi Fahui* were printed, Master Chongxu, Zhang Benzhen, commissioned a craftsman to carve twenty pages of explanatory notes to resolve doubts, enabling readers to have a reference. Chongxu may be said to be deeply devoted to the Dao and courageous in upholding righteousness.

*Zhouyi Cantong Qi Fahui Shiyi*

The *Imperially Commissioned Complete Library of the Four Treasuries*
*Masters Section, Volume 14*
*Elucidations on the Uniting of the Three in Accordance with the Zhou Changes*
*Daoist School*

**Editorial Summary**

We, your ministers, respectfully observe: *Elucidations on the Uniting of the Three in Accordance with the Zhou Changes* in three *juan*, with one *juan* of *Resolving Doubts*, was composed by Yu Yan of the Song. Yan’s *Collected Explanations of the Zhou Changes* has already been recorded. This work expounds the Dao of cinnabar elixirs through the water and fire, yin and yang of the human body. Though it does not match the specialized Daoist scholarship of the three commentaries by Peng Xiao, Chen Xianwei, and Chen Zhixu, its sources are exceedingly broad. Its three chapters of *Resolving Doubts* examine discrepancies and similarities, surpassing even Zhu Xi’s edition in thoroughness and clarity.

The *Catalogue of the Daoist Canon* by Yunji Daolu states that the two works together comprise fourteen *juan*, while Jiao Hong’s *Bibliographic Treatise of the History of the Realm* records twelve *juan*. Mao Jin’s *Treasured Writings from the Ford of Jin* combines Yan’s commentary with the three commentaries of Xiao and the others into a single compilation, deviating from the original. Moreover, it omits *Resolving Doubts*, which has since been lost. This edition includes illustrations in every *juan* and was printed in the third year of the Zhida era (1310) by Zhang Yufeng, the succeeding Celestial Master. It consists solely of three *juan* of *Elucidations*, with one *juan* of *Resolving Doubts* appended.

An examination of Yan’s preface to *Other Writings on the Changes* also describes the oral instructions of the cinnabar Dao as meticulously preserved in the three chapters of *Elucidations on the Uniting of the Three in Accordance with the Zhou Changes*. The record in Yunji Daolu may have conflated this work with others, while Jiao Hong’s account appears to have been copied and distorted from other sources, rendering it increasingly unreliable.

Respectfully submitted in the sixth month of the forty-fifth year of the Qianlong reign (1780).
**Chief Compilers:**
Minister Ji Yun

**Preface to the Reprinted *Elucidations on the Uniting of the Three in Accordance with the Zhou Changes***

Of old, when the sages composed the *Changes*, it began with Fuxi, who received the *Hetu* and drew the trigrams. King Wen expanded them and appended the hexagram statements; the Duke of Zhou extended the six positions to determine fortune and misfortune and appended the line statements. Confucius, following the *Great* and *Lesser Images*, composed the *Ten Wings*. Its fundamental principle lies in the *taiji*: when it moves, it generates yang; when it rests, it generates yin. Once the Two Modes are divided, the Four Images are established. Movement and stillness mutually serve as their root, giving rise to the Five Phases. Through the interplay of yin and yang, odd and even, the Eight Trigrams are formed. The Yellow Emperor commanded Da Rao to create the *jiazi* cycle: its ten stems and twelve branches merely explore the nature of the Five Phases, yet they too do not depart from the directional positions of the Eight Trigrams. When trigrams are doubled, they become sixty-four hexagrams; when divided, they yield three hundred eighty-four lines. Thus, there is the Dao of Heaven, the Dao of Earth, and the Dao of Man. With the Dao of the Three Powers complete, all things filling Heaven and Earth possess principle, qi, image, and number. Their waxing and waning, advance and retreat, preservation and destruction—none fall outside the sage’s compass, for he discerns and comprehends their underlying causes. Therefore, the *Book of Changes* is vast and all-encompassing. By means of it, teachings are established, and the methods of calendrical calculation and divination are founded upon the Five Phases and Eight Trigrams, sufficient to disclose things and accomplish tasks, thereby guiding the people. Indeed, the *Changes* is for the counsel of the noble person—how can one not employ it?

Yet the world does not embody the ceaseless movement of Heaven and Earth, does not explore the mutual generation and restraint of the Five Phases, nor follow the ebb and flow of hexagrams and lines. Acting recklessly, they fail to return to themselves, unaware of what cultivation and refinement entail. Few are those who preserve their seven-foot bodies and return them whole. How much less can they hope for longevity and enduring vision amidst Heaven and Earth?

Those of the immortal lineage who attain longevity and enduring vision do so through the Dao of the returned elixir. However, the immortals of antiquity necessarily possessed esoteric transmission and oral instruction; their secret formulas were seldom lightly disclosed. Thus, few accounts of them exist in the world. Some, not following the great Dao but relying on private cleverness, claim that crooked shortcuts are easily traversed or that heterodox byways lead to attainment. The worst of them consume desiccating medicines, drink noxious drafts, and ingest poisonous pellets, mistaking them for divine elixirs—only to lose their lives and forfeit their years. How can they preserve longevity?

By the Later Han, Wei Boyang recognized that the Dao of the returned elixir must not be led astray by perverse doctrines but must be rooted in the Dao of the *Changes*. For the Dao of the *Changes* encompasses the mechanism of yin and yang, movement and stillness, and embraces the marvel of hexagram and line transformation—ceaselessly generating, endlessly transforming. Now, when we turn inward to observe our bodies, are they not also a Heaven and Earth? The primordial qi we receive is none other than the qi of Heaven and Earth. If Heaven and Earth endure, why can we not emulate them?

This is why the *Cantong qi* was composed. *Can* means to consult the *Changes* and find no error; *tong* means to align with the *Changes* and find no discrepancy; *qi* means to silently comprehend and naturally preserve the *Changes*. Formerly, I heard that the immortals of old possessed the method of refining the elixir. Once the elixir was completed, one could ascend in flight, achieving longevity. Thus, the famous mountains and scenic places of the world all bear the strange traces of furnaces and crucibles. Alas! The odd stones in the mountains that occasionally resemble furnaces and crucibles are but coincidences. Upon reading this book, I realized that the notion of refining the elixir in furnaces and crucibles is delusion. The teachings of the immortals on guiding and refining cultivation operate within; they do not rely on external means. What is taken lies within oneself; it does not depend on...

What is sought lies within oneself, not in external things. Gold, for instance, is prized for its purity—unmixed, unadulterated. Without refining it with lead and mercury through fire, how could one attain its true essence, its unyielding hardness, to form the elixir and emulate the immortality of Heaven and Earth? Now, the *Cantong qi* borrows this principle: it takes the Qian and Kun of one’s body as the crucible, the Kan and Li—the sun and moon—as the medicinal ingredients. By concentrating the spirit and gathering the *qi*, causing the Dragon and Tiger to unite in essence and interact, advancing the fire phases to await their transformations, the Dao of the elixir may be accomplished.

Yet this book, though examined and annotated by Master Zhu Ziyang, still leaves many doubts unresolved. Though it provides a thread of understanding, the very materials and apertures remain obscure—how much more so for those beneath Master Zhu’s level of insight? In the Zhiyuan era, Master Yuyu, Quanyangzi, first delved deeply into this text. Initially, he failed to grasp its subtleties, finding it exceedingly difficult. Only through long accumulation of effort and unwavering faith did enlightenment come as if by divine revelation. Thereafter, he gathered the secret formulas of various perfected ones and compared them with this book, finding no discrepancy with the teachings of the *Changes*. Thus, he expounded upon this work, adding annotations that illuminated the Dao of the elixir as clearly as pointing to one’s palm.

Yet while the method of the returned elixir is said to be supremely simple and easy—accessible to all—it is also spoken of as requiring three years and nine cycles, appearing easy but proving difficult in truth. It demands prolonged dedication. Therefore, those who study the Dao in hopes of becoming immortals must not measure it hastily or glimpse it superficially. They must seek its doors and windows, examine its gates and pivots, wield the bellows and key, advance the fire phases, and guard the Dragon and Tiger until their union. Then the Yellow Sprout will grow of itself, the Jade Flower will manifest, and the Dao of the returned elixir will be within reach.

With this, one may ascend in flight, achieve eternal existence, ride the long clouds between the eight poles, and brave the fierce winds of the nine heavens—utterly severed from the world, dwelling in the divine isles, forever ascending the immortal’s throne. Once in a hundred generations, one descends to wander among mortals, bestowing long life and salvation, while none can fathom their whereabouts. Looking down upon the ephemeral world, where mayflies flicker in the morning and gnats rise and fall, it is truly not worth even a laugh.

The Qian and Kun are the gates and doors of the *Yi*, the father and mother of all hexagrams. Closing the door is called Kun; opening the door is called Qian. One closing and one opening is called *change*; endless coming and going is called *communication*—this is why Qian and Kun are the gates and doors of the *Yi*. Qian gives birth to three sons; Kun gives birth to three daughters. Male and female unite in essence, and the myriad things are transformed and born—this is why Qian and Kun are the father and mother of all hexagrams.

The human body models Heaven and emulates Earth, sharing the same yin and yang as Heaven and Earth. If one understands that this body shares the same yin and yang with Heaven and Earth, then one may discuss the Dao of the returned elixir.

Kan and Li form the encompassing frame, turning the wheel with the axle as its center. Kan is the moon; Li is the sun. The sun and moon travel along the ecliptic, circulating endlessly day and night, like the revolving frame of a wheel. The hub is like the body; the axle is like the heart. If one wishes the hub to turn, one must align the axle. For those who cultivate the returned elixir, circulating the sun and moon within their body to follow the same path as Heaven and Earth’s creative transformations—how could they not rectify their heart?

The four hexagrams of the female and male serve as the bellows and pipe, covering and veiling the Dao of yin and yang, just as a charioteer holds the reins and bit with precision, adhering to the guiding line, following the tracks, maintaining the center to regulate the exterior. The numbers are recorded in the calendar’s monthly nodes: five or six weave the warp and weft, serving the sun to combine into sixty. Hard and soft have their inner and outer aspects. At dawn, *Zhun* governs affairs; at dusk, *Meng* receives its turn. Day and night each correspond to one hexagram, used in sequence. Before reaching the dim light of dawn, the cycle ends and begins anew.

Qian is the pure yang, male hexagram; Kun is the pure yin, female hexagram. Kan contains yang within yin; Li contains yin within yang—these are the hexagrams of female and male union. The elixir method positions Qian and Kun above and below, arranges Kan and Li to the east and west, so that the opening and closing of Qian and Kun, the coming and going of Kan and Li, resemble the form of bellows and pipe. Thus it is said: "The four hexagrams of the female and male serve as bellows and pipe." The bellows and pipe are empty vessels—the bellows is the leather sack, the pipe its tube. The *Daodejing* of Laozi states: "Is not the space between Heaven and Earth like a bellows?" Empty yet inexhaustible, moving yet ever-producing. The great void’s vastness resembles the body of the bellows; the opening and closing, coming and going of qi resemble its function. Knowing this, one has grasped more than half of the Dao of the returned elixir.

Yet this Dao exists when grasped and perishes when released. Therefore, one must guard one’s inner realm and restrain one’s outer conduct, as in the *Liezi: Chongxu Zhide Zhenjing*, which speaks of the charioteering of the Taidou clan. Only then may one engage in this practice. For the charioteering of the Taidou clan is to harmonize the reins and bit with utmost precision, adjusting swiftly or slowly as needed.

The harmony of lips and tongue is precisely measured within the chest, while rhythm is maintained in the grip of the hands. Between palm and grasp, the center is inwardly attained, and outwardly, the horse’s will is met. Thus can one advance and retreat as if treading a taut line, or turn and curve as if compass and square. The method of refining the elixir is likewise.

The numbers in the *lü* and calendric reckonings circulate through twelve positions: twelve pitches of the *lü* correspond to twelve months, and twelve years to a cycle. The monthly nodes of five and six arise from dividing a thirty-day month into six nodes. The warp is the fixed positions of Qian and Kun, north and south; the weft is the subtle workings of Kan and Li, east and west. The "servant of the sun" follows the sun’s command, its timing moving in perfect accord with the heavens, rising and setting without the slightest deviation.

The combination yields sixty: the *Book of Changes* has sixty-four hexagrams, but excluding Qian, Kun, Kan, and Li, exactly sixty remain. Each day has twelve hours, with two hexagrams governing affairs, each line corresponding to one hour—two hexagrams totaling twelve lines, matching the numbers of the *lü* and calendric reckonings. Combined with a thirty-day month, this yields sixty hexagrams. Arranging sixty hexagrams within a thirty-day month, at dawn of the new moon, *Zhun* governs the morning and *Meng* the evening; day and night’s twelve hours precisely correspond to two hexagrams and twelve lines. From there, morning *Xu* and evening *Song*, morning *Shi* and evening *Bi*, follow in sequence until the month’s end, when *Jiji* and *Weiji* are used. From dark moon to new moon, the cycle repeats endlessly. Within these hexagrams, the inner and outer, hard and soft bodies may reverse or oppose one another—none of this need be rigidly adhered to.

As Zhang Ziyang’s *Wuzhen Pian* states:
*"Herein grasp the meaning, seek not the image;
To exhaust the lines is but to labor in vain."*
For the sixty hexagrams are not rigidly assigned within a thirty-day month.

Some, failing to comprehend this principle, cling to the doctrine of hexagram images, asserting that two hours of the day serve as the firing times, meticulously measuring the weight of lines to gauge the qi’s timing. Day and night, they anxiously watch the sundial and water clock—how grievously mistaken!

The sun and stars set the measure; movement and stillness vary in earliness and lateness. Chen Niju’s *Cuixu Pian* says: *"The heavens clearly divide twelve forms; all take them as the program for elixir refinement."* This refers to the sun and stars as the measure. The sun is fire; the stars are the timing. If one can reverse the heavens’ sun and stars to seek them within the body, then the position of the sun’s arrival becomes the hour. The *Wuzhen Pian* states: *"To refine the medicine, know dawn and dusk"*—this refers to movement and stillness varying in earliness and lateness. Movement is rising at sunrise to work; stillness is resting at sunset. Within our own bodies, there is naturally a sunrise and sunset, early and late. The firing times and movements of stillness and activity all secretly align with the celestial measures, none but using the pivot of the heavens and the tides of time as the moments for inner work.

In spring and summer, rely on the inner body, from *zi* to *chen* and *si*; in autumn and winter, employ the outer, from *wu* to *xu* and *hai*. Hexagrams have six lines: the lower three are inner, the upper three outer. Take, for example, the morning use of *Zhun* and evening use of *Meng*. Morning *Zhun* is the time of yang fire’s ascent, and *Zhun*’s *chujiu* line corresponds to *zi* within the body, moving from inner to outer—hence *"in spring and summer, rely on the inner body, from *zi* to *chen* and *si*."* Evening *Meng* is the time of yin tally’s descent, and *Meng*’s *shangjiu* line corresponds to *wu* within the body, moving from outer to inner—hence *"in autumn and winter, employ the outer, from *wu* to *xu* and *hai*."*

Yet the so-called spring, summer, autumn, and winter; *zi*, *wu*, *si*, and *hai*; and the doctrines of inner body and outer use are all metaphors. If one rigidly adheres to images and texts, practicing hexagram qi, one merely grasps Qian and Kun as the crucible, kneads the crow and hare as medicine, and cooks them—how could this refer to the Qian and Kun outside the body, the crow and hare outside the body? The seeker must seek them within the body.

chunks.original_text: 上地位乎 下二气则运行乎 其中一升一降往来不穷犹橐钥也 人受冲和之气生于天地间与天地初无二体若能悟天地橐钥之妙此心冲虚湛寂自然一气周流于上下开则气出阖则气入气出则如地气之上升气入则如天气之下降自可与天地齐其长乆子华子云古之知道者筑垒以防邪防源以毓真深居静处不为物撄动息出入而与神气俱防魄守戒谨窒其兑专一不分真气乃存上下灌注气乃流通如水之流如日月之行而不休阴营其藏阳固其府源流泏泏满而不溢冲而不盈夫是之谓乆生舍此而曰我自有登云捷法则是旁蹊曲学非吾大丹之道也 天地者乾坤之象也设位者列阴阳配合之位也易谓坎离坎离者乾坤二用二用无爻位周流行六虚往来既不定上下亦无常 干为天坤为地吾身之鼎器也离为日坎为月吾身之药物也先天八卦干南坤北离东坎西南北列天地配合之位东西分日月出入之门反而求之吾身其致一也乾坤其体也坎离其用也坎离二者周流升降于六虚往来上下盖无爻位吾身之坎离运行乎鼎器之内潜天而天潜地而地亦岂有爻位哉 幽潜沦匿变化于中 幽潜沦匿者神入气中气入脐中而沉归海底去也变化于中者时至气自化静极机自发而抱出日头来也陈希夷指篇云邈无踪迹归武潜有机关结圣胎此之谓也 包裹万物为道纪纲 悟真篇云道自虚无生一气便从一气产阴阳阴阳再合生三体三体重生万物张盖金丹之母不过先天一气而已裂而为二分而为三散而为万皆自此一气中来故曰包裹万物为道纪纲 以无制有器用者空 道德经云三十辐共一毂当其无有车之用埏埴以为器当其无有器之用凿户牖以为室当其无有室之用故有之以为利无之以为用林鬳斋注云毂车之容轴者也 辐轮之股也 毂惟虚中故可以行车埏埴陶者之器也 虚而圆故可以成器户牖室中之通明处也 此三者皆是譬喻虚者之为用故曰有之以为利无之以为用车器室皆寔有之利也 而其所以为车为器为室皆虚中之用今魏公谓以无制有器用者空实用老子之盖丹法以太虚为鼎炉而太虚之中自有天然妙用奇哉 奇哉 关尹子云衣揺空得风气嘘物得水陈抱一注云知揺空得风则鼓吾橐钥可以生气知嘘物得水则胎吾之气可以化精苟昧此而他求所谓鼎器则非虚无之道矣 故推消息坎离没亡 息者进火之候坤三变而成干也消者退符之候干三变而成坤也今自朔旦震卦用事之后历兑至干望罢巽卦用事之后历艮至坤其间不见坎离爻位是谓坎离没亡欤曰坎离非没亡也行乎六虚之间而往来不定尔 言不苟造论不虚生引验见效校度神明推结字原理为征坎戊月精离巳日光日月为易刚柔相当土王四季罗络始终青赤白黑各居一方皆禀中宫戊巳之功 坎外阴而内阳月之象也 离外阳而内阴日之象也 坎纳戊戊阳土也 离纳己巳阴土也 二土交合则阴阳相济刚柔相当犹日月两字合之而辏成易字也 青赤白黑即木火金水也 木火金水各居一方惟土居中央分旺辰戌丑未而罗络一岁之始终是故木得之以旺火得之以息金得之以生水得之以止四者皆禀其功也 然是土也 遍满乎
chunks.translated_text:
Above lies the position of earth, below the two qi circulate—ascending and descending in endless alternation, like a bellows. Man, born of harmonious qi between heaven and earth, shares the same original body with them. If one awakens to the bellows’ marvel of heaven and earth, this heart becomes empty, still, and serene, and qi naturally flows throughout above and below. When it opens, qi issues forth; when it closes, qi enters in. Qi issuing forth resembles earth qi ascending; qi entering resembles heaven qi descending. Thus may one equal heaven and earth in longevity.

Master Zihua said: "The ancients who understood the Dao built ramparts to guard against the perverse and dammed the source to nurture the true. Dwelling in seclusion, undisturbed by things, they regulated their breath to unite with spirit and qi. Guarding the po, observing precepts, they sealed their senses, focused without distraction—thus true qi was preserved. Above and below, it irrigated; qi flowed unimpeded, like water’s current, like the sun and moon’s ceaseless motion. Yin nourished the viscera; yang fortified the bowels. The source flowed abundantly, full yet not overflowing, balanced yet not brimming—this is called long life."

To abandon this and claim, "I possess a swift method to ascend the clouds," is but a devious byway of misguided learning, not the great elixir’s Way.

Heaven and earth are the images of Qian and Kun. The established positions are the arrayed stations of yin and yang’s pairing. The *Yi* speaks of Kan and Li: Kan and Li are Qian and Kun’s two functions. Without fixed lines or positions, they circulate through the six voids, their coming and going unfixed, their above and below without constancy.

Qian is heaven; Kun is earth—our body’s crucible. Li is the sun; Kan is the moon—our body’s medicine. The precelestial eight trigrams place Qian in the south and Kun in the north, Li in the east and Kan in the west. South and north array the positions of heaven and earth’s pairing; east and west divide the gates of sun and moon’s ingress and egress. Reversing the search to seek within our body, the principle is one.

Qian and Kun are the substance; Kan and Li are the function. These two, Kan and Li, circulate, ascending and descending through the six voids, coming and going above and below—indeed, without fixed lines or positions. Within our body’s crucible, Kan and Li move: heaven hides in the latent, earth hides in the latent—how could there be fixed lines or positions?

Concealed and submerged, they transform within. "Concealed and submerged" means spirit enters qi, qi enters the navel, and sinks to return to the sea’s depths. "Transforming within" means when the time arrives, qi naturally transmutes; when stillness reaches its extreme, the mechanism spontaneously activates, and the sun’s orb is embraced and brought forth. As Chen Xiyi’s *Zhi Pian* says: "Vast, without trace, returning to the mysterious; latent, with mechanisms, the sacred embryo is knit"—this is the meaning.

Enveloping the ten thousand things as the Dao’s guiding principle, the *Wuzhen Pian* states: "The Dao arises from emptiness and nonbeing; from the one qi, yin and yang are produced. Yin and yang unite to generate the three bodies; the three bodies engender the ten thousand things." The mother of the golden elixir is none other than the precelestial one qi. Split, it becomes two; divided, it becomes three; dispersed, it becomes the ten thousand things—all emerge from this one qi. Thus it is said: "Enveloping the ten thousand things as the Dao’s guiding principle."

To use the insubstantial to govern the substantial, the vessel’s function is emptiness. The *Daode Jing* says: "Thirty spokes share one hub; it is the center’s emptiness that makes the cart useful. Clay is shaped into vessels; it is the hollowness within that makes the vessel useful. Doors and windows are cut to make a room; it is the empty space that makes the room useful. Thus, what is present provides the advantage; what is absent provides the function."

Lin Yanzhai’s commentary states: "The hub is the part of the wheel that holds the axle; the spokes are the wheel’s limbs. The hub is empty in the center, hence it can move the cart. Clay is the potter’s material; hollow and round, it can become a vessel. Doors and windows are the room’s passages for light—these three are all metaphors for the function of emptiness. Thus it is said: 'What is present provides the advantage; what is absent provides the function.' Carts, vessels, and rooms are all real advantages, yet their usefulness as cart, vessel, or room lies in the function of emptiness."

Now, Master Wei’s statement—"to use the insubstantial to govern the substantial, the vessel’s function is emptiness"—truly employs Laozi’s meaning. In the elixir method, the great emptiness serves as crucible and furnace, and within the great emptiness, there naturally exists a wondrous function. Marvelous! Marvelous!

Guan Yinzi says: "Clothing sways in the void to obtain wind; exhaling upon things obtains water." Chen Baoyi’s commentary states: "Knowing that swaying in the void obtains wind, then striking our bellows can generate qi. Knowing that exhaling upon things obtains water, then nurturing our qi can transform essence." If one is ignorant of this and seeks elsewhere, the so-called crucible and furnace are not the Way of emptiness and nonbeing.

Thus, advancing and retreating, Kan and Li vanish and reappear. "Advancing" is the time for kindling the fire, when Kun’s three lines transform into Qian. "Retreating" is the time for withdrawing the tally, when Qian’s three lines transform into Kun. Now, from the new moon when the Zhen trigram governs, passing through Dui to Qian, and from the full moon when the Xun trigram governs, passing through Gen to Kun, Kan and Li’s line positions are unseen—is this not the vanishing of Kan and Li?

Yet Kan and Li do not vanish; they move through the six voids, their coming and going unfixed.

Words are not carelessly crafted; theories are not idly born. Drawing evidence, verifying effects, measuring with spirit and numen, tracing the origins of characters to confirm principles: Kan is the essence of the wu month; Li is the light of the si day. Sun and moon are the *Yi*’s correlates of firm and yielding. Earth rules the four seasons, weaving the warp of beginning and end. Green, red, white, and black each occupy a quarter, all receiving the power of the central palace’s wu and si.

Kan is yin without and yang within—the image of the moon. Li is yang without and yin within—the image of the sun. Kan receives wu, the yang earth; Li receives ji, the yin earth. When the two earths unite, yin and yang harmonize, firm and yielding correspond—like the two characters for sun and moon combining to form the character *yi*. Green, red, white, and black are wood, fire, metal, and water. Wood, fire, metal, and water each occupy a quarter; only earth resides in the center, dividing its flourishing seasons among chen, xu, chou, and wei to weave the warp of the year’s beginning and end. Thus, wood receives its flourishing, fire its rest, metal its birth, and water its cessation—all receive its power.

Yet this earth pervades everywhere...

Yet the so-called spring, summer, autumn, and winter; *zi*, *wu*, *si*, and *hai*; and the doctrines of inner body and outer use are all metaphors. If one rigidly adheres to images and texts, practicing hexagram qi, one merely grasps Qian and Kun as the crucible, kneads the crow and hare as medicine, and cooks them—how could this refer to the Qian and Kun outside the body, the crow and hare outside the body? chunks.original_text: 宇内本无定位焉 在坎则为戊土在离则为己土在中宫则为戊己土在四季则为辰戌丑未土均是物也 防哉 悟真篇之诗有曰四象五行全借土又曰只缘彼此怀真土遂使金丹有返还盖非真土调和则阴阳否隔刚柔离分不能成丹也 呜呼魏公作是书以发明斯道之秘无非引验见效亲到实诣之复恐其未足以取信于后人遂又校度日月之神明以为法推原易卦之道理以为证可谓深切而着明矣 又岂肯苟造无稽之言虚生无益之论以诳惑后之来者哉 易者象也悬象着明莫大乎日月穷神以知化阳往则阴来辐辏而轮转出入更卷舒 易者象也 即上文所谓日月为易是也 夫魏公之为是也 将以指陈身中之阴阳而身中之阴阳则无形可求百姓日用而不知苟非假象托物将何以发明而使人穷其神知其化哉 于是仰观俯察乎 天地之间惟有日月之象显然着明故以其显然着明者示人使之洞见天地之阴阳而默识乎 神化之妙则吾身之日用不知者自可以不言而喻也 盖日月往来乎 黄道之上一出一入迭为上下互为卷舒昼夜循环犹如车轮之运转无有穷己人能反身而思之触而长之则吾一身之中自有日月与天地亦无异矣 韩逍遥内指通秘诀云法轮要转常须转只在身中人不见驾动之时似日轮日轮向我身中转又云法轮转得莫停留念念不离轮自转何用外求哉 易有三百八十四爻据爻摘符符谓六十四卦 一部全易计三百八十四爻一斤大药计三百八十四铢此丹道易道之相通而参同契所以作也爻者卦画也符者卦之合体也易有六十四卦丹法以乾坤为鼎器以坎离为药物以其余六十卦为火候今以乾坤观之始于屯防终于既济未济其间反体对体无一不相合于此见一阴一阳之谓道而古仙据爻摘符以比喻鼎器药物火候可谓巧且备矣 晦至朔旦震来受符当斯之时天地构其精日月相撢持 晦至朔旦者晦朔之间也
chunks.translated_text:
Within the universe, there is no fixed position for earth—when in Kan, it is wu earth; when in Li, it is ji earth; when in the central palace, it is wu-ji earth; when in the four seasons, it is chen-xu-chou-wei earth. Yet it is the same substance. How profound! The *Wuzhen Pian* poem states: "The Four Symbols and Five Phases all rely on earth," and again: "Only because each holds true earth within does the golden elixir achieve return and restoration." For without true earth to harmonize them, yin and yang remain blocked, firm and yielding sundered—no elixir can form.

Alas! When Master Wei composed this book to reveal the secrets of this Dao, he drew only from verified evidence and personal attainment. Yet fearing this might still fail to convince later generations, he further calibrated the numinous workings of sun and moon as a method and traced the principles of the *Yi* hexagrams as proof—truly profound and luminous. How could he have idly fabricated groundless words or spun useless theories to deceive those who come after?

The *Yi* is imagery. No image is more luminous than that of sun and moon. To fathom the numinous and know transformation: when yang departs, yin arrives; they converge like spokes in a turning wheel, alternating in ebb and flow. The *Yi* is imagery—precisely what the earlier passage meant by "sun and moon forming *yi*."

Master Wei’s purpose in this work was to point out the yin and yang within the body. Yet the body’s yin and yang are formless and ungraspable—ordinary people use them daily without awareness. If not for borrowing images and objects, how could one illuminate them so that others might fathom the numinous and know transformation? Thus, he looked up and down between heaven and earth, where only the images of sun and moon stand out in luminous clarity. By presenting what is manifestly clear, he enabled others to perceive the yin and yang of heaven and earth and silently grasp the wonders of transformation. Then the daily workings of one’s own body, though unspoken, become self-evident.

For sun and moon traverse the ecliptic: one emerges, one retreats; they alternate above and below, intertwining in expansion and contraction, cycling through day and night like a wheel turning endlessly. If one reflects inwardly and extends this insight, one finds that within one’s own body, sun and moon exist no differently than in heaven and earth.

Han Xiaoyao’s *Neizhi Tongxuan Mijue* states:
*"The Dharma-wheel must turn—always turn—*
*Yet it lies within the body, unseen.*
*When set in motion, it resembles the sun-wheel—*
*The sun-wheel turns toward me, within my body."*
And again:
*"Let the Dharma-wheel turn without cease;*
*Thought by thought, cling not—*
*The wheel turns of itself;*
*What need is there for external seeking?"*

The *Yi* contains three hundred eighty-four lines. "Extracting the tally" refers to the sixty-four hexagrams—a complete *Yi* totals three hundred eighty-four lines, while one *jin* of the great medicine totals three hundred eighty-four *zhu*. This is the resonance between the Dao of the elixir and the Dao of the *Yi*, and thus the *Cantong Qi* was composed.

The lines are the strokes of the hexagrams; the tally is the union of hexagrams. The *Yi* has sixty-four hexagrams. In the elixir method, Qian and Kun serve as the cauldron and vessel, Kan and Li as the medicinal substances, and the remaining sixty hexagrams as the fire phases. Now, observing Qian and Kun: they begin with *Zhun* and end with *Jiji* and *Weiji*, with every inversion and correspondence in between perfectly aligned. Herein lies the Dao: "One yin, one yang." The ancient immortals, by extracting the tally from the lines, metaphorically compared cauldron, medicinal substances, and fire phases—truly ingenious and comprehensive.

From the dark of the moon to the dawn of the new moon, Zhen arrives to receive the tally. At this moment, heaven and earth conjoin their essence, and sun and moon mutually sustain each other. "From the dark of the moon to the dawn of the new moon" refers to the interval between the last and first days of the lunar month.

chunks.original_text: 震来受符者干交于坤而成震身中之一阳生也 斯时神与气交气与神合有如天地之构精日月之合璧故曰当斯之时天地构其精日月相撢持天地即吾身之乾坤也 日月即吾身之坎离也 天地日月以时而相交故能陶万汇而成岁功乾坤坎离以时而相交故能夺造化而成圣胎魏公学者不明身中之阴阳造化遂借日月相交之时为喻非曰一月止有晦朔之间可以用功也 悟真篇云日月三旬一遇逢以时易日法神功学者能知以时易日之妙则能天地之机而成大丹矣 雄阳播施雌阴统黄化 雄阳播施者天气降而至于地也雌阴统黄化者地承天气而生物也悟真篇云甘露降须天地合黄芽生要坎离交盖丹法之生药与天地之生物相似皆不过阴阳二气一施一化而黄相交尔 浑沌相交接权舆树根基 阴阳二气上下交接混而为一故谓之浑沌浑沌乃天地之郛郭万物之胞胎也丹法以之为权舆而树立根基则天地万物皆在吾身而不用求之外矣 经营养鄞鄂凝神以成躯 鄞鄂即根蒂也丹法经营于此而回光内照则神恋气而凝气恋神而住自然交结成胎如其神光内泄气马外驰则日月失道金汞异炉欲望成丹不亦远乎白紫清珠玉叶丹髓歌云昔日遇师亲口诀只要凝神入气穴此所以称之为神丹而号之曰神仙也 众夫蹈以出蠕动莫不由 阴阳交接之道乃生生化化之源也不特人与禽兽由此而出虽蠉飞蠕动跂行喙息至微之莫不皆然故曰众夫蹈以出蠕动莫不由是道也施之于人则生人存之于己则生药但有圣凡逆顺之分尔 于是仲尼赞鸿蒙乾坤德洞虚稽古称元皇关雎建始初冠婚气相纽元年乃芽滋 尝观易首乾坤书称稽古诗以关雎为先礼以冠婚为重春秋以元年为第一义是知圣人之作经皆有所托始也炼丹而不究其始又安能洞晓阴阳深达造化哉 圣人不虚生上观显天符天符有进退诎信以应时符者合也月行于天一月一度与日交合故谓之天符天符有进退屈信以应时者月自初一以后光渐进魂长魄消阳伸阴屈象一日之子至己十六以后光渐退魄长魂消阴伸阳屈象一日之午至亥也古之至人观天之道执天之行遂借天符之进退阴阳之屈伸设为火候法象以示人盖天地俨如一鼎器日月乃药物也日月行乎天地间往来出没即火候也人能即此反求诸身自可默防火候进退之妙矣 故易统天心复卦建始初 易者一阴一阳之谓也
chunks.translated_text:
When *Zhen* arrives to receive the tally, it is Qian interpenetrating Kun to form *Zhen*, wherein the single yang is born within the body. At this moment, spirit and qi intermingle, qi and spirit unite—akin to heaven and earth conjoining their essence, sun and moon merging as one. Thus it is said: "At this moment, heaven and earth conjoin their essence, sun and moon mutually sustain each other." Heaven and earth are the Qian and Kun within our bodies; sun and moon are the Kan and Li within us. As heaven and earth and sun and moon unite in due season, they refine the myriad things to accomplish the year’s work. As Qian and Kun and Kan and Li unite in due season, they seize the transformations of creation to form the sacred embryo.

Master Wei sighed: scholars, failing to comprehend the yin-yang transformations within their own bodies, borrow the moment of sun-moon conjunction as a metaphor. Yet it is not that only the interval between the dark and dawn of the new moon may be employed for inner work. The *Wuzhen Pian* states: "Sun and moon meet once every thirty days; the method of exchanging days for seasons lies in spiritual work." If practitioners grasp the subtlety of exchanging days for seasons, they may seize heaven and earth’s mechanism to complete the Great Elixir.

"Yang, the male, scatters the mysterious; yin, the female, gathers the yellow transformation." "Yang, the male, scatters the mysterious" refers to heavenly qi descending to earth; "yin, the female, gathers the yellow transformation" refers to earth receiving heavenly qi to generate beings. The *Wuzhen Pian* says: "Sweet dew descends when heaven and earth unite; the yellow sprout arises when Kan and Li intermingle." The generation of medicinal substances in elixir arts resembles the generation of beings in heaven and earth—both proceed from the intermingling of yin and yang, one scattering, one transforming, to produce the mysterious yellow.

When primordial chaos intermingles, the root and foundation are established. As yin and yang qi ascend and descend to intermingle and merge as one, it is called "primordial chaos." Primordial chaos is the outer enclosure of heaven and earth, the womb of the myriad things. In elixir arts, taking this as the starting point to establish the root and foundation means that heaven, earth, and the myriad things all reside within one’s body, with no need to seek them externally.

Cultivating and nurturing within the *yinen*, spirit congeals to form the body. *Yinen* is the root and stem. When elixir arts are cultivated here and the inner light is turned inward, spirit clings to qi and congeals, qi clings to spirit and abides—naturally interweaving to form the embryo. If the spirit’s light leaks outward and the qi-steed gallops abroad, then sun and moon lose their way, gold and mercury part crucibles. How then may one hope to complete the elixir? The *Baizi Qingzhu Yuye Dansui Ge* says: "In former days, I met my teacher and received the oral transmission: simply focus spirit to enter the qi-cavern." This is why it is called "spirit-elixir" and named "spirit-immortal."

All beings tread this path to emerge, even the wriggling and crawling. The way of yin-yang intermingling is the source of all generation and transformation. Not only do humans and beasts emerge thereby; even the flying, wriggling, crawling, and breathing—down to the most minute creatures—all proceed from this. Thus it is said: "All beings tread this path to emerge; the wriggling and crawling none are without it." Applied to others, it generates people; preserved within oneself, it generates the medicinal substance. The only distinction lies in whether one is sagely or common, moving with or against the current.

Thus Confucius praised the *Hong Meng*, saying: "The virtue of Qian and Kun pervades the empty." Ancient texts esteemed the *Yuan Huang*; the *Guanju* established the beginning. The *Book of Rites* took capping and marriage as weighty; the *Spring and Autumn Annals* made the first year paramount. From this we know that the sages’ composition of classics all had a foundational reference. If one practices elixir arts without investigating their origins, how may one thoroughly comprehend yin-yang and deeply penetrate the transformations of creation?

The sage is not born in vain; above, he observes the celestial tally. The celestial tally has advance and retreat, contraction and extension, in accord with the seasons. The tally is the union: the moon travels through the heavens, once each month uniting with the sun, hence called the celestial tally. The celestial tally has advance and retreat, contraction and extension in accord with the seasons: from the first day of the month onward, its light gradually advances, the *hun* lengthens, the *po* wanes, yang extends, yin contracts—like the progression from midnight to noon. From the sixteenth day onward, its light gradually retreats, the *po* lengthens, the *hun* wanes, yin extends, yang contracts—like the progression from noon to midnight. The perfected of old observed heaven’s way and grasped heaven’s movements, then borrowed the celestial tally’s advance and retreat, yin-yang’s contraction and extension, to establish the method of fire phases as a model for others. For heaven and earth are like a single crucible, sun and moon the medicinal substances. The sun and moon’s movements through heaven and earth—coming and going, rising and setting—are the fire phases. If one can turn inward to seek this within oneself, one may silently grasp the subtlety of the fire phases’ advance and retreat.

Thus the *Yi* unites the heart of heaven; the *Fu* hexagram establishes the beginning. The *Yi* is called "one yin, one yang."

chunks.original_text: 天心北方子之中也 复十一月之卦也 复之为卦正当北方子位之中气应冬至邵康节击壤集冬至吟云冬至子之半天心无改移是也 朱晦庵以为康节此诗最好盖立冬是十月初小雪是十月中大雪是十一月初冬至是十一月中小寒是十二月初大寒是十二月中冬至子之半即十一月之半也 人言夜半子时为冬至盖夜半以前一半属子时今推五行者多不知之然数每从这处起略不差移此所以为天心今魏公为易统天心复卦建始初者阳气潜萌于孟冬纯阴之月而始于坤卦之下积成一画之阳然后变为复卦也 人固知十月为坤至十一月则五阴之下变一阳画而为复殊不知十一月冬至无缘平白便生一画之阳遽变为复盖十月小雪坤下爻己有阳生其中但一日之内一月之间方长得三十分之一必积之一月至十一月冬至始满一画为复然此亦譬喻也 年以冬至为复月以朔旦为复日以子时为复无非借以发明身中造化殆不必泥于年月日时也 翠虚篇云一月三旬一日同修丹法象夺天功盖年与月同月与日同日与时同于是蹙年成月蹙月成日蹙日成时一时之中自有一阳来复之机是机也 不在冬至不在朔旦亦不在子时非深达天地阴阳莫知机如是其秘也 长子继父体因母立兆基 干父下交于坤母之初爻而成震震为长男故曰长子继父体震自坤体而生犹婴儿生于母腹中故曰因母立兆基悟真篇云金公本是东家子送在西邻继体生与此同防知此则知炼丹不用寻冬至身中自有一阳生而不泥乎年月日时之矣 消息应钟律升降据斗枢 自子至巳为息自午至亥为消消息应钟律者钟律于一岁十二月之内每月换一管一岁换尽十二律吾身火候之消息亦犹是也自下而上为升自上而下为降升降据斗枢者斗枢于一日十二时之内每时移一位一日移遍十二辰吾身火候之升降亦犹是也指篇云寥寥九地移钟管黯黯长天运斗魁盖不过取象比喻而已即非用律管之短长天罡之所指而为期度也 三日出为爽震受庚西方 月三日哉生明昏在西方庚位其象如震应震卦之纳庚若以吾身之火候言之则所谓河车不敢暂留停之时是也 八日兑受丁上平如绳 月至八日为上昏在南方丁位其象如兑应兑卦之纳丁以喻吾身阳火上升之半也 十五干体就盛满甲东方 月至十五与日相望昏在东方甲位其象如干应干卦之纳甲以喻吾身阳火盛满之候也 蟾蜍与兔魄日月无双明 蟾蜍者月之精兔魄者日之光日月无双明者日以昱乎昼月以昱乎夜日出则月没月出则日没昼夜递照而出入更卷舒也人之呼吸何异于是哉岂不见黄庭经云出日入月呼吸存盖呼吸即日月也 蟾蜍视卦节兔者吐生光 丹法以上半月为阳属震兑干下半月为阴属巽艮坤故曰蟾蜍视卦节月为太阴日为太阳阳主吐阴主纳月本无光受日之光而白故曰兔者吐生光 七八道己讫屈折低下降 七八即十五也阳火自震而升至于十五纯干则巳满上半月之候其势极矣其道危矣盖不容不屈曲折旋而低降也陈朝元玉芝书云九重城里龙车发十二楼前虎驾回即此义也 十六转受统巽辛见平明 月至十六日既生魄晨在西方辛位明乍亏其象如巽应巽卦之纳辛以吾身火候言之则阴受阳禅峰回路转之时也 艮直于丙南下二十三 月至二十三日为下晨在南方丙位明半亏其象如艮应艮卦之纳丙以喻吾身阴符下降之半也 坤乙三十日东方防其明
